017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ycwcm;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.Interpolations;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.Interpolations.InterpolationFunction;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.MathTools;
023import com.github.tommyettinger.ds.FloatList;
024
025/**
026 * Static methods for handling gradients of smoothly-changing colors, typically inside of {@link FloatList}s.
027 * The intent is for the FloatList to be used as a sequence of packed float YCwCm colors. You can create a new
028 * FloatList gradient with {@link #makeGradient(float, float, int, InterpolationFunction)}, but any FloatList will work
029 * (although it only makes sense if it contains packed float colors or is empty). Once you have a FloatList, you can
030 * pass it to {@link #appendGradient(FloatList, float, float, int, InterpolationFunction)} to make a gradient between two
031 * colors, or {@link #appendGradientChain(FloatList, int, InterpolationFunction, float...)} to make a gradient between more
032 * than two colors. You can also customize each section between colors with
033 * {@link #appendPartialGradient(FloatList, float, float, int, InterpolationFunction)}, which is just like appendGradient() but
034 * doesn't add the end color (since it is the start color of the next partial gradient, until you finally end by
035 * appending just the end). Using appendPartialGradient(), you can have each transition use a different number of steps.
036 */
037public class GradientTools {
038    /**
039     * No need to instantiate.
040     */
041    private GradientTools(){
042    }
043
044    /**
045     * Creates a FloatList gradient from the packed float YCwCm color {@code start} to the packed float YCwCm color
046     * {@code end}, taking the specified number of steps and using linear interpolation.
047     * @param start the packed float YCwCm color to start with
048     * @param end the packed float YCwCm color to end on
049     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2, and must be non-negative
050     * @return a new FloatList that contains the requested gradient
051     */
052    public static FloatList makeGradient(float start, float end, int steps) {
053        return makeGradient(start, end, steps, Interpolations.linear);
054    }
055    /**
056     * Creates a FloatList gradient from the packed float YCwCm color {@code start} to the packed float YCwCm color
057     * {@code end}, taking the specified number of steps and using the specified InterpolationFunction for how it transitions.
058     * @param start the packed float YCwCm color to start with
059     * @param end the packed float YCwCm color to end on
060     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2, and must be non-negative
061     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
062     * @return a new FloatList that contains the requested gradient
063     */
064    public static FloatList makeGradient(float start, float end, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation) {
065        FloatList appending = new FloatList(steps);
066        if(steps <= 0) {
067            return appending;
068        }
069        if(steps == 1) {
070            appending.add(start);
071            return appending;
072        }
073        appendPartialGradient(appending, start, end, steps - 1, interpolation).add(end);
074        return appending;
075    }
076
077    /**
078     * Appends a gradient from the packed float YCwCm color {@code start} to the packed float YCwCm color {@code end},
079     * taking the specified number of steps and using linear InterpolationFunction for how it transitions.
080     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
081     * @param start the packed float YCwCm color to start with
082     * @param end the packed float YCwCm color to end on
083     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
084     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
085     */
086    public static FloatList appendGradient(FloatList appending, float start, float end, int steps) {
087        return appendGradient(appending, start, end, steps, Interpolations.linear);
088    }
089    /**
090     * Appends a gradient from the packed float YCwCm color {@code start} to the packed float YCwCm color {@code end},
091     * taking the specified number of steps and using the specified InterpolationFunction for how it transitions.
092     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
093     * @param start the packed float YCwCm color to start with
094     * @param end the packed float YCwCm color to end on
095     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
096     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
097     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
098     */
099    public static FloatList appendGradient(FloatList appending, float start, float end, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation) {
100        if(appending == null)
101            return null;
102        if(steps <= 0) {
103            return appending;
104        }
105        if(steps == 1) {
106            appending.add(start);
107            return appending;
108        }
109        appending.ensureCapacity(steps);
110        appendPartialGradient(appending, start, end, steps - 1, interpolation).add(end);
111        return appending;
112    }
113
114    /**
115     * Appends a gradient between several packed float YCwCm colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses linear
116     * InterpolationFunction for the whole gradient. Appends to the end of {@code appending} and produces a total of
117     * {@code steps} colors.
118     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
119     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
120     * @param chain an array or varargs of packed float YCwCm colors that this will interpolate through in order
121     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
122     */
123    public static FloatList appendGradientChain(FloatList appending, int steps, float... chain) {
124        return appendGradientChain(appending, steps, Interpolations.linear, chain);
125    }
126
127    /**
128     * Appends a gradient between several packed float YCwCm colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses linear
129     * InterpolationFunction for the whole gradient. Appends to the end of {@code appending} and produces a total of
130     * {@code steps} colors.
131     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
132     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
133     * @param chain a FloatList of packed float YCwCm colors that this will interpolate through in order
134     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
135     */
136    public static FloatList appendGradientChain(FloatList appending, int steps, FloatList chain) {
137        return appendGradientChain(appending, steps, Interpolations.linear, chain);
138    }
139
140    /**
141     * Appends a gradient between several packed float YCwCm colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses the specified
142     * InterpolationFunction for the whole gradient, which can make some colors use smaller sections than others. Appends to the
143     * end of {@code appending} and produces a total of {@code steps} colors.
144     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
145     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
146     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
147     * @param chain a FloatList of packed float YCwCm colors that this will interpolate through in order
148     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
149     */
150    public static FloatList appendGradientChain(FloatList appending, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation, FloatList chain) {
151        if (appending == null)
152            return null;
153        if(chain == null)
154            return appending;
155        if (steps <= 0 || chain.size() == 0) {
156            return appending;
157        }
158        if (steps == 1 || chain.size() == 1) {
159            appending.add(chain.first());
160            return appending;
161        }
162        appending.ensureCapacity(steps);
163        int limit = steps - 1, splits = chain.size() - 1;
164        float step = 1f / steps, change = 0f;
165        for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
166            float interp = interpolation.apply(change);
167            float splint = Math.min(Math.max(interp * splits, 0f), splits - 0.000001f);
168            int idx = (int)splint;
169            appending.add(FloatColors.lerpFloatColors(chain.get(idx), chain.get(idx+1), MathTools.norm(idx, idx +1, splint)));
170            change += step;
171        }
172        appending.add(chain.get(splits));
173        return appending;
174    }
175
176    /**
177     * Appends a gradient between several packed float YCwCm colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses the specified
178     * InterpolationFunction for the whole gradient, which can make some colors use smaller sections than others. Appends to the
179     * end of {@code appending} and produces a total of {@code steps} colors.
180     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
181     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
182     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
183     * @param chain an array or varargs of packed float YCwCm colors that this will interpolate through in order
184     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
185     */
186    public static FloatList appendGradientChain(FloatList appending, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation, float... chain) {
187        if (appending == null)
188            return null;
189        if(chain == null)
190            return appending;
191        if (steps <= 0 || chain.length == 0) {
192            return appending;
193        }
194        if (steps == 1 || chain.length == 1) {
195            appending.add(chain[0]);
196            return appending;
197        }
198        appending.ensureCapacity(steps);
199        int limit = steps - 1, splits = chain.length - 1;
200        float step = 1f / steps, change = 0f;
201        for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
202            float interp = interpolation.apply(change);
203            float splint = Math.min(Math.max(interp * splits, 0f), splits - 0.000001f);
204            int idx = (int)splint;
205            appending.add(FloatColors.lerpFloatColors(chain[idx], chain[idx+1], MathTools.norm(idx, idx +1, splint)));
206            change += step;
207        }
208        appending.add(chain[splits]);
209        return appending;
210    }
211
212    /**
213     * Exactly like {@link #appendGradient(FloatList, float, float, int)}, but does not include
214     * {@code end} in what it appends to {@code appending}. This is intended for the implementation of chained
215     * gradients, where the end of a previous gradient becomes the start of the next one. This still uses the specified
216     * number of steps, it just doesn't append {@code end} in the last step.
217     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
218     * @param start the packed float YCwCm color to start with
219     * @param end the packed float YCwCm color to end just before
220     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
221     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to its end
222     */
223    public static FloatList appendPartialGradient(FloatList appending, float start, float end, int steps) {
224        return appendPartialGradient(appending, start, end, steps, Interpolations.linear);
225    }
226    /**
227     * Exactly like {@link #appendGradient(FloatList, float, float, int, InterpolationFunction)}, but does not include
228     * {@code end} in what it appends to {@code appending}. This is intended for the implementation of chained
229     * gradients, where the end of a previous gradient becomes the start of the next one. This still uses the specified
230     * number of steps, it just doesn't append {@code end} in the last step.
231     * @param appending a FloatList that will be appended to
232     * @param start the packed float YCwCm color to start with
233     * @param end the packed float YCwCm color to end just before
234     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
235     * @param interpolation a libGDX InterpolationFunction that can be used to customize how start transitions toward end
236     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to its end
237     */
238    public static FloatList appendPartialGradient(FloatList appending, float start, float end, int steps, InterpolationFunction interpolation){
239        if(appending == null)
240            return null;
241        if(steps <= 0) {
242            return appending;
243        }
244        if(steps == 1) {
245            appending.add(start);
246            return appending;
247        }
248        int limit = steps;
249        float step = 1f / steps, change = 0f;
250        for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
251            appending.add(FloatColors.lerpFloatColors(start, end, interpolation.apply(change)));
252            change += step;
253        }
254        return appending;
255    }
256}
